♠ Handheld firearms ♣ {absent; present} ♥ Guns and snorkels were introduced shortly after the Second World War. [246] The game population was virtually exterminated after the introduction of guns in the 1950s. [247] This conflicts with Kituai's account of a WW I-related incident: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [248] The constabulary was armed with rifles and trained in a paramilitary fashion: 'Second, the Papua New Guinean policemen of the period did not receive professional training the same way as a teacher, lawyer, or economist. There were no hard theories to be learned, for instance, in social anthropology, to assist them in their work, and no mind-stretching examinations to be sat. A policeman’s training from the 1890s to the 1960s was brief and intellectually slight, both from the traditional perspective and in comparison to the training given today. […] Apart from that, their important achievement was as part of a small mobile army unit -foot patrolling, keeping guard using the rifle, and maintaining law and order. In this they were quite effective. […] If however, during their service they performed diligently and achieved things in a manner in keeping with those who received professional training, then credit must go to the noncommissioned officers and officers who continued their training in the field -and to their own initiative, innate abilities, and understanding of local conditions.' [249]

Handheld weapons[edit]

♠ War clubs ♣ present ♥ Stone Clubs. Stone clubs are of two principal kinds, the ‘pineapple’ (gishi) and the disk (emi). They are made from river pebbles. The former variety has a hole through the longer axis for the haft, and its striking surface is serrated by means of longitudinal and lateral grooves, which leave a number of processes or points. The latter is more or less disk-shaped, the outer edge being ground down to a fairly sharp cutting-edge.[250] Wooden ‘Swords’. The wooden sword (asivo) is a blade-shaped length of black palm-wood usually some 3 feet 6 inches long. The point and edges are not so sharp as to pierce or cut, and the weapon is virtually a club. Being used with two hands, it is much less unwieldy than the stone-headed club, and probably gains in effectiveness by its lightness. The asivo is often painted and befeathered.[251]
♠ Battle axes ♣ present ♥ As the miners and carriers moved into Gira River and Yodda Valley districts there was more violence between villagers and intruders. Over a period of about 18 months, large numbers of Kumusi villagers joined with the Kokoda people to attack miners and storekeepers nearly every week. Resident Magistrate Armit intervened in an attempt to reduce the tension, but in various encounters with parties of Orokavians armed with stones, spears and tomahawks, he shot between fifty and sixty.[252]
♠ Daggers ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Swords ♣ absent ♥ (NB: Oro "Swords" were all wooden; Williams & Murray describe them as "virtually a club"[253] (see above) and it has been coded as such.)
♠ Spears ♣ present ♥ Spears. The principal weapon is the spear, of which several varieties are distinguished.[254] One or two varieties of hard-woods are used for spears, but these weapons as well as the wooden ‘sword’ are usually made from the tough and springy Koropa palm.[255] The significance of warfare to Orokaivan men is obvious but several descriptions suggest that Orokaivan women were also directly involved. Women had their own weapon, a quarterstaff ‘poreha’ (Williams 1930:163) and on at least one occasion joined in with the men in spear fighting. On most occasions it seems that women used only their staffs and fought alongside men in aggressive sham fights between clans (Waiko 1972, Williams 1930:162-163). They were more noted for their verbal contribution. The people most difficult to pacify were women, who, while doing little actual violence with their … quarterstaffs, were very successfully inciting to violence with their tongues (Williams 1930:163).[256]
♠ Polearms ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Other ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Animals used in warfare[edit]

♠ Dogs ♣ absent ♥
♠ Donkeys ♣ absent ♥
♠ Horses ♣ absent ♥
♠ Camels ♣ absent ♥
♠ Elephants ♣ absent ♥
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥

Armor[edit]

♠ Wood, bark, etc ♣ present ♥ [NB: only in shields.] The Shield. The shield (beha or pere) is made of light wood, about ½ inch thick, strongly bound with narrow strips of cane to prevent splitting. The handle is a loop of stout rattan which passes through the wood. The shape of the shield-square cut above and pointed below-caused early observers to refer to it very appropriately as ‘Gothic’. It sometimes bears a device-in no manner heraldic but purely decorative-made by interlacing black strands among the yellow cane binding strips; and when this is well done the effect may be artistic and even dainty (Plate XIX)... Shields are used very adroitly in turning or intercepting missiles, and a broken spear-point buried in the wood is regarded as a trophy. Despite the fact that their serious use is over they are still very commonly kept in readiness-at least by the Aiga-and they always make a fracas possible. Like most other men the Orokaiva has no stomach for the plain spear, and he enjoys his inter-tribal brawl much more when he has a beha in his hand.[257]
♠ Leather, cloth ♣ absent ♥
♠ Shields ♣ present ♥ The Shield. The shield (beha or pere) is made of light wood, about ½ inch thick, strongly bound with narrow strips of cane to prevent splitting. The handle is a loop of stout rattan which passes through the wood. The shape of the shield-square cut above and pointed below-caused early observers to refer to it very appropriately as ‘Gothic’. It sometimes bears a device-in no manner heraldic but purely decorative-made by interlacing black strands among the yellow cane binding strips; and when this is well done the effect may be artistic and even dainty (Plate XIX)... Shields are used very adroitly in turning or intercepting missiles, and a broken spear-point buried in the wood is regarded as a trophy. Despite the fact that their serious use is over they are still very commonly kept in readiness-at least by the Aiga-and they always make a fracas possible. Like most other men the Orokaiva has no stomach for the plain spear, and he enjoys his inter-tribal brawl much more when he has a beha in his hand.[258]
♠ Helmets ♣ absent ♥ This may require reconsideration, given the presence of colonial forces on the island.
♠ Breastplates ♣ absent ♥
♠ Limb protection ♣ absent ♥
♠ Chainmail ♣ absent ♥
♠ Scaled armor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Laminar armor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Plate armor ♣ absent ♥

Naval technology[edit]

♠ Small vessels (canoes, etc) ♣ present ♥ With few exceptions the trees are soft-woods, and these supply easy material for canoes and much of the house-building.[259] The Binandere “built canoes and explored the river, extending their settlement wherever land was suitable” (Chinnery and Beaver 1917:160).[260]
♠ Merchant ships pressed into service ♣ absent ♥
♠ Specialized military vessels ♣ {absent; present} ♥ This variable may also be in need of reconsideration. Kituai mentions armed naval vessels when narrating German punitive expeditions and the early colonial situation in general, primarily in the capacity of providing supplies and assistance to land forces, and occasional bombardments. [261]

Fortifications[edit]

♠ Settlements in a defensive position ♣ present ♥ Villages were often built on hill-tops (where there were any hills) by way of defence, and many such sites are marked by clusters of coco-nut palms in the Tain-Daware district. In these easy-going times they have been abandoned for more accessible positions.[262]
♠ Wooden palisades ♣ present: 1884-1900 CE; [absent; present]: 1901-1922 CE; absent: 1923-1942 CE ♥ It seems that in certain cases at least the village was provided with some kind of stockade, though no trace of these defences remains to-day.[263] In former times, if native accounts are to be trusted, villages were more extensive through need of mutual protection against the raider; and a resident magistrate patrolling the river Gira in 1901 speaks of a village 200 yards long by two chains broad, which contained seventy-one houses and was ‘barricaded in with a look-out and fighting platforms on the stockade’. But nowadays [1923] pacification has brought about a tendency to scatter in small isolated groups.[264] Norton (1962:6) says that sometimes villages, which ‘are known to have been quite large’ and stockaded (cf. Williams 1930:67, 164-6), were separated by tracts of unclaimed virgin land until the time of the suppression of feuding.[265] That warfare was a constant in precontact Orokaivan life is also borne out by descriptions of material defence arrangements. Villages along the Kumusi, Ope, Mambare and Gira rivers, in particular, were reported to be stockaded in many cases and several had lookout platforms in large trees. In 1906 the Resident Magistrate reported fighting in the Kumusi area in which 102 houses, including several tree-houses, were burned.[266]
♠ Earth ramparts ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ditch ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Williams and Murray report the construction of spear pits: 'As a last point may be mentioned the miniature spear-pits (see p. 49) with which the paths were sometimes beset. They are mentioned as occurring in the Kokoda district, often beside a tree-trunk that has fallen across the path, so that the unwary might step over the log and into the trap. Several of the police had their feet spiked in this manner. Near Bogi, again, Mr. Alec Elliot, attacking a force of natives established in a strong position on the opposite side of a garden, found this garden to be ‘one mass of small spears and spear-pits’.' [267] Whether these traps qualify as fortifications remains in question.
♠ Moat ♣ absent ♥
♠ Stone walls (non-mortared) ♣ absent ♥
♠ Stone walls (mortared) ♣ absent ♥
♠ Fortified camps ♣ absent ♥
♠ Complex fortifications ♣ absent ♥
♠ Long walls ♣ 0 ♥ km.
♠ Modern fortifications ♣ absent ♥ Whether colonial military forts were constructed remains in need of confirmation.


Other technologies[edit]

Military Organization[edit]

♠ Standing armies ♣ {absent; present} ♥ In addition to groups of warriors from diverse local communities, foreign military was present throughout the colonial period: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [268] The constabulary was armed with rifles and trained in a paramilitary fashion by colonial officers: 'Second, the Papua New Guinean policemen of the period did not receive professional training the same way as a teacher, lawyer, or economist. There were no hard theories to be learned, for instance, in social anthropology, to assist them in their work, and no mind-stretching examinations to be sat. A policeman’s training from the 1890s to the 1960s was brief and intellectually slight, both from the traditional perspective and in comparison to the training given today. […] Apart from that, their important achievement was as part of a small mobile army unit -foot patrolling, keeping guard using the rifle, and maintaining law and order. In this they were quite effective. […] If however, during their service they performed diligently and achieved things in a manner in keeping with those who received professional training, then credit must go to the noncommissioned officers and officers who continued their training in the field -and to their own initiative, innate abilities, and understanding of local conditions.' [269] [Jonathan Ritchie (pers. comm.): On the military, I think pre-War this means the Police… and during the War, we’re looking at the Papuan Infantry Battalion - perhaps either Jim Sinclair’s To Find a Path - The Life and Times of the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment or G.M. Byrnes’ Green Shadows will help? The first recruits for the PIB were 70 from the Buna area - who I think were all drawn from the Royal Papuan Constabulary - who came in July 1940, supplemented by another 62 in May 1941. 'Military training was carried out until August 28, 1940 when everybody was put on road construction. During November, 24-hour guard duty was ordered at key points in the Port area [of Port Moresby]…. Until the end of August 1941 the guarding of vulnerable points, together with working parties on roads and wharves and training were the duties of the battalion. During September the battalion was allotted the defence area from Napa Napa to Jolers Bay. Recce (Reconnaissance) parties covered this area and the two companies moved out to positions in the allotted areas and began constructing tactical roads and defence positions. Working parties were practically discontinued as guard duties and intensive training were the order of the day.’ (from Byrnes, pp. 5-6).]

♠ Uniformity of equipment ♣ {absent; present} ♥ In addition to groups of warriors from diverse local communities, foreign military was present throughout the colonial period: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [270] The constabulary was armed with rifles and trained in a paramilitary fashion by colonial officers: 'Second, the Papua New Guinean policemen of the period did not receive professional training the same way as a teacher, lawyer, or economist. There were no hard theories to be learned, for instance, in social anthropology, to assist them in their work, and no mind-stretching examinations to be sat. A policeman’s training from the 1890s to the 1960s was brief and intellectually slight, both from the traditional perspective and in comparison to the training given today. […] Apart from that, their important achievement was as part of a small mobile army unit -foot patrolling, keeping guard using the rifle, and maintaining law and order. In this they were quite effective. […] If however, during their service they performed diligently and achieved things in a manner in keeping with those who received professional training, then credit must go to the noncommissioned officers and officers who continued their training in the field -and to their own initiative, innate abilities, and understanding of local conditions.' [271] [Jonathan Ritchie (pers. comm.): On the military, I think pre-War this means the Police… and during the War, we’re looking at the Papuan Infantry Battalion - perhaps either Jim Sinclair’s To Find a Path - The Life and Times of the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment or G.M. Byrnes’ Green Shadows will help? The first recruits for the PIB were 70 from the Buna area - who I think were all drawn from the Royal Papuan Constabulary - who came in July 1940, supplemented by another 62 in May 1941. 'Military training was carried out until August 28, 1940 when everybody was put on road construction. During November, 24-hour guard duty was ordered at key points in the Port area [of Port Moresby]…. Until the end of August 1941 the guarding of vulnerable points, together with working parties on roads and wharves and training were the duties of the battalion. During September the battalion was allotted the defence area from Napa Napa to Jolers Bay. Recce (Reconnaissance) parties covered this area and the two companies moved out to positions in the allotted areas and began constructing tactical roads and defence positions. Working parties were practically discontinued as guard duties and intensive training were the order of the day.’ (from Byrnes, pp. 5-6).]

♠ Total army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Professional army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Largest fielded army ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Maximum logistical lag ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Sources of recruits ♣ mass mobilization ♥ 'The tribal fight (isoro) probably involves an expedition in which a number of clans combine. The war signal-either for the alarm or the assembly, for both mean the same thing-is a fast-throbbing rhythm on the hui, called onomatopoeically ‘kikiki. …’ (In these days of peace the same signal announces the arrival of a Government patrol, though the alarm is happily less acute.) The attacking force having assembled by day usually travels by night, with the intention of surrounding the devoted village and surprising it at dawn. These tactics, however, are not invariable: the raiders are better satisfied with random victims, such as an isolated fishing party.' [272] In addition to groups of warriors from diverse local communities, foreign military was present throughout the colonial period: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [273] The constabulary was armed with rifles and trained in a paramilitary fashion by colonial officers: 'Second, the Papua New Guinean policemen of the period did not receive professional training the same way as a teacher, lawyer, or economist. There were no hard theories to be learned, for instance, in social anthropology, to assist them in their work, and no mind-stretching examinations to be sat. A policeman’s training from the 1890s to the 1960s was brief and intellectually slight, both from the traditional perspective and in comparison to the training given today. […] Apart from that, their important achievement was as part of a small mobile army unit -foot patrolling, keeping guard using the rifle, and maintaining law and order. In this they were quite effective. […] If however, during their service they performed diligently and achieved things in a manner in keeping with those who received professional training, then credit must go to the noncommissioned officers and officers who continued their training in the field -and to their own initiative, innate abilities, and understanding of local conditions.' [274] The code may therefore be in need of reconsideration.

♠ Procurement of equipment and animals ♣ by soldiers ♥ 'It was customary for women to accompany the expedition carrying pots of food; and they might even stand by their husbands as armour-bearers. Sir William MacGregor, ascending the Kumusi in 1894, noted that ‘The men carried generally a spear and a shield each, with a woman behind him bearing two or three spears. The women were able-bodied, and unaccompanied by children or small boys. Apparently they were simply armour-bearers.’ Again, on the same river in 1895 he met many armed natives, ‘the warrior being frequently followed by a woman carrying part of his panoply, or ready to relieve him of his arms when he was induced to dispense with them.’' [275] In addition to groups of warriors from diverse local communities, foreign military was present throughout the colonial period: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [276] The constabulary was armed with rifles and trained in a paramilitary fashion by colonial officers: 'Second, the Papua New Guinean policemen of the period did not receive professional training the same way as a teacher, lawyer, or economist. There were no hard theories to be learned, for instance, in social anthropology, to assist them in their work, and no mind-stretching examinations to be sat. A policeman’s training from the 1890s to the 1960s was brief and intellectually slight, both from the traditional perspective and in comparison to the training given today. […] Apart from that, their important achievement was as part of a small mobile army unit -foot patrolling, keeping guard using the rifle, and maintaining law and order. In this they were quite effective. […] If however, during their service they performed diligently and achieved things in a manner in keeping with those who received professional training, then credit must go to the noncommissioned officers and officers who continued their training in the field -and to their own initiative, innate abilities, and understanding of local conditions.' [277] The code may therefore be in need of reconsideration.

General Characteristics of Warfare[edit]

Types of Warfare[edit]

♠ Inter-polity wars ♣ present ♥ 'This pattern of alliance with, or fighting against, the Europeans was similar to the traditional pattern of warfare outlined above, but the fighting arena had changed. The Europeans represented forces and institutions fundamentally different from anything the Orokaiva had hitherto encountered. In response to the trauma of initial contact and the frightening power of firearms, Orokaiva River villagers extended their social horizons further than they had needed to previously. An example of this can be seen in incidents described by the Assistant Resident Magistrate at Bogi, A. Elliot. Dwellers on the coastal side of the Kumusi River united with those on the other side to assist their ‘daily’ fighting of the white man. According to Elliot, between seven and eight thousand attended a feast after the death of carriers and whites (Walker, PNG Archives 1901, G91, 6577, 684c; PAR 1900-01:11).' [278] There was a short WW I-related incident in 1914: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [279]

♠ Internal wars ♣ present ♥ 'In the process of this continual fighting, some tribes were virtually exterminated, the only survivors being captives who later intermarried with the victors. Other tribes whose numbers were depleted by warfare amalgamated and gradually lost their cultural-linguistic distinctiveness. There was no pattern of permanent alliance. A single tribe could not be relied upon continually to side with another, nor could it even avoid the outbreak of hostilities between the clans of which it was composed.' [280]

♠ Intra-elite conflicts ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Popular uprisings ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Military revolts ♣ suspected unknown ♥

♠ Separatist rebellions ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Cultural distance[edit]

♠ Wars within same ethnic group ♣ present ♥ In the process of this continual fighting, some tribes were virtually exterminated, the only survivors being captives who later intermarried with the victors. Other tribes whose numbers were depleted by warfare amalgamated and gradually lost their cultural-linguistic distinctiveness. There was no pattern of permanent alliance. A single tribe could not be relied upon continually to side with another, nor could it even avoid the outbreak of hostilities between the clans of which it was composed.[281]

♠ Wars involving groups with different dialects ♣ present ♥ In the process of this continual fighting, some tribes were virtually exterminated, the only survivors being captives who later intermarried with the victors. Other tribes whose numbers were depleted by warfare amalgamated and gradually lost their cultural-linguistic distinctiveness. There was no pattern of permanent alliance. A single tribe could not be relied upon continually to side with another, nor could it even avoid the outbreak of hostilities between the clans of which it was composed.[282]

♠ Wars involving groups with different languages ♣ present ♥ In the process of this continual fighting, some tribes were virtually exterminated, the only survivors being captives who later intermarried with the victors. Other tribes whose numbers were depleted by warfare amalgamated and gradually lost their cultural-linguistic distinctiveness. There was no pattern of permanent alliance. A single tribe could not be relied upon continually to side with another, nor could it even avoid the outbreak of hostilities between the clans of which it was composed.[283]

♠ Wars involving groups with different language families ♣ present ♥ 'This pattern of alliance with, or fighting against, the Europeans was similar to the traditional pattern of warfare outlined above, but the fighting arena had changed. The Europeans represented forces and institutions fundamentally different from anything the Orokaiva had hitherto encountered. In response to the trauma of initial contact and the frightening power of firearms, Orokaiva River villagers extended their social horizons further than they had needed to previously. An example of this can be seen in incidents described by the Assistant Resident Magistrate at Bogi, A. Elliot. Dwellers on the coastal side of the Kumusi River united with those on the other side to assist their ‘daily’ fighting of the white man. According to Elliot, between seven and eight thousand attended a feast after the death of carriers and whites (Walker, PNG Archives 1901, G91, 6577, 684c; PAR 1900-01:11).' [284] Consider also the WW I-related incident mentioned above.

♠ Wars between groups from different archaeological cultures ♣ ♥

♠ Wars between different religious sects ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars between different world religions ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars of world religion against tribal religion ♣ present ♥ This pattern of alliance with, or fighting against, the Europeans was similar to the traditional pattern of warfare outlined above, but the fighting arena had changed. The Europeans represented forces and institutions fundamentally different from anything the Orokaiva had hitherto encountered. In response to the trauma of initial contact and the frightening power of firearms, Orokaiva River villagers extended their social horizons further than they had needed to previously. An example of this can be seen in incidents described by the Assistant Resident Magistrate at Bogi, A. Elliot. Dwellers on the coastal side of the Kumusi River united with those on the other side to assist their ‘daily’ fighting of the white man. According to Elliot, between seven and eight thousand attended a feast after the death of carriers and whites (Walker, PNG Archives 1901, G91, 6577, 684c; PAR 1900-01:11).[285]

♠ Wars on Urbanism-Literacy frontier ♣ present ♥ This pattern of alliance with, or fighting against, the Europeans was similar to the traditional pattern of warfare outlined above, but the fighting arena had changed. The Europeans represented forces and institutions fundamentally different from anything the Orokaiva had hitherto encountered. In response to the trauma of initial contact and the frightening power of firearms, Orokaiva River villagers extended their social horizons further than they had needed to previously. An example of this can be seen in incidents described by the Assistant Resident Magistrate at Bogi, A. Elliot. Dwellers on the coastal side of the Kumusi River united with those on the other side to assist their ‘daily’ fighting of the white man. According to Elliot, between seven and eight thousand attended a feast after the death of carriers and whites (Walker, PNG Archives 1901, G91, 6577, 684c; PAR 1900-01:11).[286]

♠ Wars on steppe frontier ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars on agricultural frontier ♣ absent ♥

Intensity of warfare[edit]

♠ Annexation ♣ present ♥ If it was rare it occurred. This is binary coding. Relative importance requires another form of analysis.

Annexation was rare: 'Conquering groups operating from within their established territorial frontiers seem seldom to have set out with the express aim of acquiring new land for settlement or even to have used the vacated land when they forced their enemies to withdraw.'[287]

'Conquering groups operating from within their established territorial frontiers seem seldom to have set out with the express aim of acquiring new land for settlement or even to have used the vacated land when they forced their enemies to withdraw.'[288]

'Some descriptions suggest that the purpose of warfare may have been to secure better land, but this was by no means always the case. Many wars were over the breach of tribal boundaries and the violation of hunting rights (Chinnery and Beaver 1917:158, 160; Waiko 1972a:12, 24)... Good land and security from attack almost certainly affected choice in area of settlement. However, the Orokaivan area is not densely populated so land shortage cannot be posited as a main cause of warfare. The uncentralized fragmentary political system relied on buffer zones between hamlets and villages. Tracts of unused land were therefore a feature of this system, marked by dispersion, splitting and war, and could be seen as exemplifying the under-use of resources which Sahlins (1972:42-51) claims for his domestic mode of production... Factors other than land shortage encouraged fighting. Youths may not have ‘lusted for a fight’ or ‘burned to distinguish themselves’ (Chinnery and Beaver 1917:159, 160) but homicide was the mark of an initiated man. A death usually demanded vengeance, so the cycle of killing and revenge was self-perpetuating. Quarrels could begin with minor matters such as garden theft, or wife beating when the wife's kinsmen came to her support. The various Orokaiva groups constantly sought to maintain their own structural position, their strength and authority, while simultaneously attempting to limit the dominance of other similar groups. Thus, fighting was an important means by which a social group continued to survive (Waiko 1972a; Chinnery and Beaver 1917:158-60).'[289]

After WW I, the German possessions on the island were transferred to Australian authorities under a League of Nations mandate: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [290] It is somewhat unclear whether this should be considered an annexation, give how the colonial enterprise can be characterized as such on a general level.

♠ Looting ♣ suspected unknown ♥

The destructiveness of colonial punitive expeditions is still somewhat unclear, although Kituai mentions bombardment of villages by German warships. [291] Actions committed against this polity does not count here. We are interested in recording only what this polity did.

♠ Sack ♣ suspected unknown ♥

The destructiveness of colonial punitive expeditions is still somewhat unclear, although Kituai mentions bombardment of villages by German warships. [292] Actions committed against this polity does not count here. We are interested in recording only what this polity did.

♠ Rape ♣ present ♥ 'Needless to say there were no conventions of war, no gratuitous mercy, and no sportingness. Men-young or old-were killed; old women were killed; young women might be raped and killed or borne off to become captive wives; children were killed or made prisoners. Though, on the other hand, there was no gratuitous cruelty, the victims were not tortured; and captive women and children were treated with kindness.'[293]

♠ Deportation ♣ suspected unknown ♥

The destructiveness of colonial punitive expeditions is still somewhat unclear, although Kituai mentions bombardment of villages by German warships. [294] Actions committed against this polity does not count here. We are interested in recording only what this polity did.

♠ Expulsion ♣ suspected unknown ♥ This code may require reconsideration, as Kituai's material suggests otherwise: 'Two tribes in Gende are composed mostly of refugees from Gembogl, North Simbu. The ancestors of these people fled from their enemies long before pacification.' [295]

♠ Enslavement ♣ present ♥ Women and children were frequently taken captive: 'Needless to say there were no conventions of war, no gratuitous mercy, and no sportingness. Men-young or old-were killed; old women were killed; young women might be raped and killed or borne off to become captive wives; children were killed or made prisoners. Though, on the other hand, there was no gratuitous cruelty, the victims were not tortured; and captive women and children were treated with kindness.'[296]

♠ Imprisonment ♣ present ♥ 'Needless to say there were no conventions of war, no gratuitous mercy, and no sportingness. Men-young or old-were killed; old women were killed; young women might be raped and killed or borne off to become captive wives; children were killed or made prisoners.'[297]

During a short WW I-related incident in 1914, some New Guinean fighters were imprisoned: 'In contrast to the localized, but sometimes ferocious and lethal tribal wars, two world wars came to Papua New Guinea. During World War I, Papua New Guinea almost escaped the violence. A semblance of military combat between an Australian force and German soldiers at Bitapaka, New Britain, lasted only one day […] Significantly, New Guinean police did most of the fighting and dying for the Germans. Among those who fought, 30 died from rifle fire, 10 were wounded, and 56 were taken prisoners (Mackenzie 1987, 73-74; Burnell 1915). Germany’s New Guinea possessions, then known as the “old protectorate”, included the northeast portion of the mainland, the Bismarck Archipelago, and Bougainville. They came under Australian military rule in September 1914 and remained subject to the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force (ANMEF) until civil administration was restored on 9 May 1921. Papua remained an Australian territory, while what was formerly German New Guinea became in 1921 a mandated territory under the League of Nations. Australia was given responsibility to administer both territories, this time under civilian government.' [298] Actions committed against this polity does not count here. We are interested in recording only what this polity did.

♠ Destruction ♣ present ♥

'That warfare was a constant in precontact Orokaivan life is also borne out by descriptions of material defence arrangements. Villages along the Kumusi, Ope, Mambare and Gira rivers, in particular, were reported to be stockaded in many cases and several had lookout platforms in large trees. In 1906 the Resident Magistrate reported fighting in the Kumusi area in which 102 houses, including several tree-houses, were burned. In such fights, he wrote, nothing is spared. “Men, women and children and pigs are massacred, gardens devastated, and villages destroyed (P.A.R. 1899-1900:72). Sometimes people deserted their villages and lived in long- houses in the bush for safety (P.A.R. 1900-1901:57). The villages near the Ope River were palisaded as “the people feared” the Kumusi tribes (Maguire 1903:123, Chignell 1911:319, P.A.R. 1899-1900:87, 90, P.A.R. 1900-1901:48, 54, 57).'[299]

The destructiveness of colonial punitive expeditions is still somewhat unclear, although Kituai mentions bombardment of villages by German warships.[300] Actions committed against this polity does not count here. We are interested in recording only what this polity did.

♠ Torture ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Data is contradictory.

'Needless to say there were no conventions of war, no gratuitous mercy, and no sportingness. Men-young or old-were killed; old women were killed; young women might be raped and killed or borne off to become captive wives; children were killed or made prisoners. Though, on the other hand, there was no gratuitous cruelty, the victims were not tortured; and captive women and children were treated with kindness.'[301]

'Informants have said that no captives except desirable women, and sometimes little children, were allowed to live: it was a safer thing·to kill them outright to prevent all chance of escape. There was, as far as I am aware, no such thing as torture, and the suggestion that one of the infant captives might be kept and fattened like a pig against some future occasion was regarded as horrible: how would it be thinkable to kill a child that was already calling its captives aja and mama? True torture, as far as I am aware, was never practised, though C. A. W. Monckton, as Resident Magistrate of the North-Eastern Division, writes: ‘… the Dobodura attacked and defeated the Notu, driving them from their villages and subjecting such prisoners and wounded men that fell into their hands to such fearful tortures that the Notus were panic-stricken, deserted their villages, and appealed to me for help.’ It seems probable, however, that this passage refers rather to mutilations than to an intentional infliction of pain, which, indeed, the oldest informants affirmed was never a feature of the raid.'[302]

♠ Mutilation ♣ inferred present ♥ 'True torture, as far as I am aware, was never practised, though C. A. W. Monckton, as Resident Magistrate of the North-Eastern Division, writes: ‘… the Dobodura attacked and defeated the Notu, driving them from their villages and subjecting such prisoners and wounded men that fell into their hands to such fearful tortures that the Notus were panic-stricken, deserted their villages, and appealed to me for help.’ It seems probable, however, that this passage refers rather to mutilations than to an intentional infliction of pain, which, indeed, the oldest informants affirmed was never a feature of the raid.' [303]

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ inferred absent ♥ The destructiveness of colonial punitive expeditions is still somewhat unclear, although Kituai mentions bombardment of villages by German warships. [304]

♠ General massacre ♣ present ♥ 'That warfare was a constant in precontact Orokaivan life is also borne out by descriptions of material defence arrangements. Villages along the Kumusi, Ope, Mambare and Gira rivers, in particular, were reported to be stockaded in many cases and several had lookout platforms in large trees. In 1906 the Resident Magistrate reported fighting in the Kumusi area in which 102 houses, including several tree-houses, were burned. In such fights, he wrote, nothing is spared. “Men, women and children and pigs are massacred, gardens devastated, and villages destroyed (P.A.R. 1899-1900:72). Sometimes people deserted their villages and lived in long- houses in the bush for safety (P.A.R. 1900-1901:57). The villages near the Ope River were palisaded as “the people feared” the Kumusi tribes (Maguire 1903:123, Chignell 1911:319, P.A.R. 1899-1900:87, 90, P.A.R. 1900-1901:48, 54, 57).' [305]

♠ Extermination ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.


Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mass burials ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

Ritual variables[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).

♠ RA ♣ Daniel Mullins ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Kekesi cult rites ♥ 'I witnessed the rites of Kekesi on November 26, 1914. They were performed with every appearance of sincerity and fanaticism. The man Yavevi conducted the ceremony, and seemed to be under the hypnotic influence of the man Bia, who remained throughout silent and carefully watching us. When the proceedings at all dragged, Bia would instil enthusiasm by throwing himself into a fit of convulsions from the waist upwards, jumping violently up and down while remaining in a sitting posture, and babbling unintelligibly, the saliva dropping from his mouth. In this condition he would be joined by Yavevi and some of the other men, whilst those remaining unaffected would redouble their efforts. Yavevi and Bia revived automatically, and Yavevi conducted the others through their prayer-like devotions. At the end of December the whole of the people of the Gira from the coast to Tabara and the Eia River in the west were performing the Kekesi rites as described above, with additional songs.' [306]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [307], this ritual occurs 'seasonally or less often than monthly but more often than annually'.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [308], this ritual occurs 'seasonally or less often than monthly but more often than annually'.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [309], this ritual occurs 'seasonally or less often than monthly but more often than annually'.
♠ Duration ♣ [1-6] ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [310]>, this ritual is coded as '1 to 6 hours/ long'.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 500 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [311], 'Most members of the community (50%-90%)' are 'present'. 500 is a very rough estimate.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ According to the Ritual Database [312], 'Most members of the community (50%-90%)' are 'present'. The text itself only refers to male officiants.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database [313], 'Most members of the community (50%-90%)' are 'present'.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database [314], 'Most members of the community (50%-90%)' are 'present'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database [315] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database [316] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database [317] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database [318] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [319] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [320].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [321] as 'absent'. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [322] is 3.33 (medium), largely because of possession, shaking, fits.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [323] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [324], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ ♥
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [325] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [326] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [327].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [328]>.
♠ dancing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [329] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'present'.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [330] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database [331] variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'present'.
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ The call and response singing format indicate that there were periods of entertainment throughout this ritual. According to Williams (1928: 38) "One man after another leads, singing a stave or two with the truly musical voice of the Orokaiva, and as, or almost before, he finishes, the whole chorus bursts forth with the refrain. The drums beat the distinctive Taro rhythm, viz. two equal beats followed by a pause equivalent to one of them, or time of three with the third beat missed. This rhythm, I believe, is used throughout the whole Division by the Taro singers, and, as far as I know, exclusively. It is the same rhythm as that of the dance baruga, practised long previous to the advent of Taro, save that it is considerably slower."[332]
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [333]'. There is no mention of a honour code or oath taking
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [334]'. There is no mention of a honour code or oath taking
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ absent ♥
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ absent ♥
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ absent ♥
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ present ♥ presence of ritual specialists
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ present ♥ presence of ritual specialists
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ absent ♥ 'Other offering' in the Ritual Database [335] is coded as 'absent'
♠ health costs ♣ absent ♥ There is no mention of direct health costs associated with this ritual.
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [336].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [337].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [338].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [339].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Embahi separation ceremony ♥ 'Initiates are brought from the bush into the village. Having entered the village, they form two advancing lines until a large scaffolding is reached, erected at one end of the village. Turning, the men kneel down facing the entrance from which they have come and remain in this position, still keeping silence. It is at this stage that the candidates are presented. Faint cries arise from the bush, becoming louder and louder, and the words “Shi! Shi!” mingled with yells and shrieks are distinguished, and at the same time the candidates are marshalled in, led by their guides. They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away. Still retaining their group formation, the men rush forward to the scaffold uttering horrible yells, waving their heads sideways with faces upturned to the lads, and swinging their clubs, only to retreat again. This violence and pandemonium continue through the night. At daybreak the girl candidates are led in and subjected to the same treatment in somewhat milder form. Then the candidates, male and female, are mustered on the ohu platform, where they sit completely covered with hoods of bark-cloth. Trees are pulled down in the village.' [340]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [341], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once in a lifetime ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [342], this ritual occurs 'once in a lifetime'.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database. According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [343], this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'.Inferred from the fact that both adolescents and adults, men and women, could participate [344].
♠ Duration ♣ 13 ♥ Estimate in hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [345]>, this ritual is coded as 'more than 12 hours'.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 50 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [346], 'Some members of community (<50%) where that is more than 15 persons'. 50 is a very rough estimate.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ majority ♥ Both men and women appear to participate as specialists in this ritual [347].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Both adolescents and adults, men and women, participated [348].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about textual reference on the existence of a passive audience, further research needed.). However,the group of initiands is ritually ‘harrassed’ by a group of men from their community. If the other people from the village are passive onlookers who watch the proceedings, they qualify as an audience. Will refer to Ritual Database.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ present ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database [349] is coded as 'present'.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ present ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database [350] is coded as 'present'.
♠ fear ♣ present ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database [351] is coded as 'present'.
♠ humiliation ♣ present ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database [352] is coded as 'absent'. [353]. Thomas Cressy: The participants, both male and female, are ritually chased, harassed, scared, yelled at by a mob of men. For this reason, I have changed the code to present to reflect this ritual humiliation.
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [354] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [355].
♠ pain ♣ present ♥ 'Other' negatively valenced bodily stimulation is coded in the Ritual Database [356] as 'present'. 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', and 'Superficial wound' are coded as absent, but 'Whipping/ beating of participants' is coded as present. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [357] is medium-high 4.33.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [358] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [359], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ present ♥ General rough treatment: 'They advance between the lines of men who, hitherto silent, now break up into groups, each catching a lad and running madly up and down the village, followed by the women, waving spears and all uttering cries and yells and rubbing the youngsters' arms, legs, and bodies. They now make a wild rush towards the scaffolding, throwing the lads on it, who endeavour to climb up out of reach, but are torn back by the mob and undergo further agony, until, utterly exhausted with fright and fatigue, they are allowed to climb away.' [360]
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [361] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [362] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [363].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [364].

♠ synchronous movement ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database [366] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'present'.

Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Difficult to code: initiation rituals often foster some kind of cohesion, but the source [369] provides no useful information in this regard.

♠ health costs ♣ present ♥ Participants are whipped and beaten.

♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [379].

♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [381].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Kasamba ♥ 'The singing, drum-beating, and feasting-not very exacting ceremonies-which constitute the chief ritual of the Taro cult, are together known as kasamba. At a large kasamba the scene is little different from that of the ordinary Orokaiva feast, except for a new style of singing, a certain exaggerated etiquette in the setting forth of the feast, and the excesses of those who lose control of themselves. Guest are given betel-nut and sit in an arc. Possibly a special platform or house, a sort of bandstand, has been erected for the occasion. This is called ba oro, i.e. ‘Taro men's house’, and is meant for the somewhat exclusive use of the accredited Taro men during the day, and for the chorus which is to continue throughout the night. The singers will crowd about a fire in the centre of the floor. The drums beat the distinctive Taro rhythm, viz. two equal beats followed by a pause equivalent to one of them, or time of three with the third beat missed. This rhythm, I believe, is used throughout the whole Division by the Taro singers, and, as far as I know, exclusively. It is the same rhythm as that of the dance baruga, practised long previous to the advent of Taro, save that it is considerably slower. Some sects perform a stationary and others a sort of processional dance. Some participants show signs of possession. They report that the sensations are felt in the stomach, the legs, and the head. A man made a stirring motion with his forefinger to give some idea of the revolving in his stomach, called peri peri. The real or supposed affection of the lower limbs is sufficiently evidenced by the lurching and reeling in which the Taro man so commonly indulges. Some men hear a strong buzzing in their ears so loud and distracting that they want to shout out. Others say that during the jipari they cannot see properly.' [382]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ seasonally ♥ Twice yearly. According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [383], this ritual occurs '4' 'seasonally (less often than monthly but more often than annually'. Further details on the frequency for the ritual specialist are not provided.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ seasonally ♥ Twice yearly. According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [384], this ritual occurs '4' 'seasonally (less often than monthly but more often than annually'.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [385], this ritual occurs '4' 'seasonally (less often than monthly but more often than annually'.
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [386], this ritual is coded as '2' or '1 to 6 hours/long'
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 500 ♥ in absolute numbers According to the Ritual Database [387], 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' participate. With a tribe size of roughly 1,300 people (See population variables), approximately 500 people participate.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ Citing the following quote, it is assumed that adult males elites enjoy certain privileges in performing this ritual. 'This is called ba oro, i.e. ‘Taro men's house’, and is meant for the somewhat exclusive use of the accredited Taro men during the day, and for the chorus which is to continue throughout the night.'
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ substantial minority ♥ Citing the following quote, it is a assumed that adult males enjoy certain privileges in this ritual. 'This is called ba oro, i.e. ‘Taro men's house’, and is meant for the somewhat exclusive use of the accredited Taro men during the day, and for the chorus which is to continue throughout the night.'
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ While only 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' participate [388], this ritual appears to be open to the whole polity as an audience.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The Kasamba ritual consisted of feasting, not fasting. "The rites—they hardly deserve such a name—are of an exceedingly sociable character, consisting typically of a singing in concert, to the accompaniment of drums, and of feasting with certain new forms of etiquette, the whole festive ceremony being known as Kasamba."[389]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ present ♥ Participants sing throughout the night. "This is called ba oro, i.e. ‘Taro men's house’, and is meant for the somewhat exclusive use of the accredited Taro men during the day, and for the chorus which is to continue throughout the night." [390]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ The ritual is quite convivial. "The rites—they hardly deserve such a name—are of an exceedingly sociable character, consisting typically of a singing in concert, to the accompaniment of drums, and of feasting with certain new forms of etiquette, the whole festive ceremony being known as Kasamba."[391]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ No participants are humiliated in the course of the ritual. [392]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [393] is coded as 'absent'. Detailed ethnographic descriptions of the ritual indicate that disgust was not a feature of this ritual [394]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [395]. A review of the source material, reinforces this code.[396]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [397] as 'absent'. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [398] is 0.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [399] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [400], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ present ♥ 'Some participants show signs of possession. They report that the sensations are felt in the stomach, the legs, and the head. A man made a stirring motion with his forefinger to give some idea of the revolving in his stomach, called peri peri. The real or supposed affection of the lower limbs is sufficiently evidenced by the lurching and reeling in which the Taro man so commonly indulges. Some men hear a strong buzzing in their ears so loud and distracting that they want to shout out. Others say that during the jipari they cannot see properly.' [401]
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [402] is coded as 'present'.
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [403]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ present ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [404], but betel nut is chewed.
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [405].
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: amended code, discussed with RA, changed to inferred present). 'Some sects perform a stationary and others a sort of processional dance. Some participants show signs of possession. They report that the sensations are felt in the stomach, the legs, and the head. A man made a stirring motion with his forefinger to give some idea of the revolving in his stomach, called peri peri. The real or supposed affection of the lower limbs is sufficiently evidenced by the lurching and reeling in which the Taro man so commonly indulges. Some men hear a strong buzzing in their ears so loud and distracting that they want to shout out. Others say that during the jipari they cannot see properly.' [406]. Ritual Database [407] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'. Thomas Cressy: Re-amended to present based on the evidence given.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Ritual Database [408] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'present'. Thomas Cressy: Changed to suspected unknown as the evidence does not prove synchronous movement.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'The singing, drum-beating, and feasting-not very exacting ceremonies-which constitute the chief ritual of the Taro cult, are together known as kasamba. At a large kasamba the scene is little different from that of the ordinary Orokaiva feast, except for a new style of singing, a certain exaggerated etiquette in the setting forth of the feast, and the excesses of those who lose control of themselves.' [409]. Ritual Database [410] variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'present'.
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ Singers are brought in for the occasion [411].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [412].
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [413]'. Not mentioned by source [414].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [415].
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [416].
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [417].
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ present ♥ presence of ritual specialists
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ present ♥ presence of ritual specialists
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ absent ♥ 'Other offering' in the Ritual Database [418] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [419].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' (a chicken) is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [420].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [421].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [422].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [423].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ taro medicine ritual ♥ 'A scene witnessed in the Aiga country is in many ways typical of the Taro cult, and in it we may see the medicine man at one of his characteristic tasks. A number of guests have assembled in the village of Totemaburari. The night and much of the forenoon have been spent in singing Taro songs, but still the revellers, whose endurance is greater than the jazzer's, show no signs of exhaustion. The principal Taro man, named Home, has been of late visited by his deceased father and has awoken to find a fresh supply of medicines in his hand. He now carries, strung together, a number of tiny packets, each neatly done up in a wrapping of green leaf, and each a very sizable mouthful. Upon close examination the packet proves to contain a somewhat repulsive hotchpotch, or rather salad, of five taro medicines, which have been already chewed with betel, spat out, and wrapped in the tidy, fair-seeming, little parcels to await a second chewing. At about noon Home, supported by two assistants who are like himself qualified Taro men, and attended by some twenty boisterous youths, sallies forth to perform the business of the day. This is nothing less than a wholesale medical treatment of the taro. Pushing rapidly through the garden, Home is seen to stoop and spray the medicines from his mouth over the taro leaves. He is continually tearing the husks from betel-nuts, which are necessary both to keep up his spirits and to ensure a suitably liquid medium for the ba sivo, and continually plies himself with the little green packets which contain the ba sivo itself. Here and there he pauses to break off some of the larger leaves (for the taros are well advanced and almost shoulder high). His two associates are similarly engaged, and meanwhile the chorus of young men, armed with their drums, are following or crowding around. The progress of the party is rapid and almost reckless: in reality the ceremony must conduce rather to the destruction than the growth of the taro, for the young drummers care little where they trample. The heat of the overhead sun is beyond endurance. The thirsty young men tear down bunches of sugar-cane and pounce upon the water-melons, regardless of their owners. One vociferous old woman stands in valiant defence of her melons, and a number of girls run on ahead to pluck their betel-pepper before the all-devouring chorus has reached it. But there is no lack of goodwill and merriment, and when, after almost two hours of this exceedingly strenuous employment, the Taro men return to the village, it is to partake of the feast which concludes almost every native ceremony.' [424]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [425], this ritual occurs '5' 'annually (less often than monthly but more often than annually'. Further details on the frequency for the ritual specialist are not provided.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ seasonally ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [426], this ritual occurs '5' 'annually'. Further details on the frequency for the ritual specialist are not provided.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ suspected unknown ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about any textual reference on the existence of an audience, further research needed.). According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [427], this ritual occurs '5' 'annually (less often than monthly but more often than annually'. Thomas Cressy: I have changed the code to suspected unknown until this can be confirmed by an expert.
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [428], this ritual is coded as '2' or '1 to 6 hours/long'
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 12 ♥ in absolute numbers According to the Ritual Database [429], 'Other small sub-group (<15)' participate.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ 'The principal Taro man...[who] supported by two assistants who are like himself qualified Taro men, and attended by some twenty boisterous youths, sallies forth to perform the business of the day.' [430].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ While the ritual only occurs at a single time with a relatively small number of participants, it is open to both male and females of various ages [431].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ suspected unknown ♥ (Giuseppe Innamorato: Discussed with RAs, unsure about any textual reference on the existence of an audience, further research needed.). While the ritual only occurs at a single time with a relatively small number of participants, it is open to both male and females of various ages [432]. Thomas Cressy: I have changed the code to suspected unknown until this can be confirmed by an expert.

♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [438].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [439] as 'absent'. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [440] is 0.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [441] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [442], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ present ♥ 'The heat of the overhead sun is beyond endurance. The thirsty young men tear down bunches of sugar-cane and pounce upon the water-melons, regardless of their owners.' [443]

♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [444] is coded as 'absent', but the description mentions a feast to close the ritual.
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of alcohol' in the Ritual Database [445] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ present ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [446], but betel nut is chewed.
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [447].
♠ dancing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [448] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'.
